content:
Try this; it preserves your whole existing setup.

1. Copy TB files from the old PC

- launch TB on the old PC

- go to TB menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information

- click the Application Basics > Profile Folder 'Open Folder' button

- the profile folder will open

- navigate three levels up to the AppData\Roaming folder

- close TB

- copy the AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird folder to a flash drive

---

2. Paste the copied TB files to the new PC

- open the AppData\Roaming folder on the new PC like you did above

- delete the Thunderbird folder

- replace it with the Thunderbird folder from the flash drive

- launch TB
creator: siffemoz

content:
Indylu7 said
Hi Ed, Your response is good but I attached the message which says it cannot find my Profile File! See my original post. I have searched all the c drive on the old laptop and cannot find the file. Lucille

Did you install TB on the new PC before you tried to copy the profile over? If so, you should at least see C:\Users\Indyl\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird. If so, that's what you want to remove and replace.

If you don't see C:\Users\Indyl\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird and you have installed TB, uninstall it > reinstall it > let it create a new profile (set it up as minimally as possible), then do the procedure I mentioned.

content:
Hello there info1320.



The reason that you cant receive is corruption in processing files within thunderbird. Try to rebuild the global database. Or the security software is blocking activities to recieve. You already checked these synchronisation options , oke.


1.deleting the global-messages-db.sqlite files are good to do for reindexing your emails. Close Thunderbird Open thunderbird profile map on that pc. Search for : global-messages-db.sqlite and remove / delete it. Restart Thunderbird . The program is reindexing the files ,It might take a while .

2. For the security software on that pc try to disable and re-enable that security and anti virus software. It means to do that same disabling and enabling also for the firewalls. And check the inbox for better connection now or take a test mail to that inbox. Leave it disabled for a while. Does it work again , then make that exception in the security software for Thunderbird.

3. To solve and configure this issue further is to check for outdated add-ons you can with our troubleshoot mode start these tools and configure for outdated or broken add-ons that can disturb the process. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

4. Situations can be there that normal internet and the communication to the Thunderbird software that Is blocked by the normal communication somehow between them , you might check.

5. Check for updates for Thunderbird or if this issue is still there after these fixes it can be a server sided problem or port issue try to change the old port number into to other numbers instead port 25 change that port number into 587.Take the latest release from us https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ if the Thunderbird versions are old.

content:
Presumably you're using the TB ESR version. The 'Reset Folder Order' option has only been added in TB142. https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/142.0/releasenotes/

So you can wait for the next ESR version (TB153 ESR) to be released in July 2026. Or you could give the Release version a shot (currently TB147). It can be downloaded at https://www.thunderbird.net/thunderbird/all/

Also see https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-release

Alternatively you may search for an add-on which allows to sort folders. https://addons.thunderbird.net/thunderbird/
creator: christ1

content: Thank you. Installing 147 fixed the problem.
creator: davanden

content:
You could create a filter in Thunderbird to delete everything from hotmail.com. However, that would also delete messages from legitimate hotmail.com senders. Fighting spam with static filters is futile. It is therefore recommended to use the TB built-in spam controls. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages

Also, check what spam protection capabilities your email provider offers. Using filters on your email providers server could prevent spam messages to even reach your computer. Depending on your account type you may need to check for false positives on the server though.
creator: christ1

content: One more tip: If the account is IMAP, I suggest having the filter COPY the messages to the Local Folder archive folder. Then, after a successful copy, change the filter to 'delete' and run again. Doing the archive process this way ensures the messages are free from the account and the space used within the account is freed. Otherwise, if you just MOVE the messages, you are not achieving the objective of creating a separate folder from the account. Be sure to do backups, as the archives are on your PC.
creator: davidsk

content: I do not understand your problem. It needs more detail. I successfully test plus addressing and it works as intended. Part of your issue may be that you have a filter that strips the message. My understanding is that this is a feature of gmail. If you set up plus addresses as aliases in gmail, you can send and receive it. So, a message from a person using 'emailaddress+joe@gmail.com, can be readily replied to as emailaddress+joe@gmail.com. What am I not understanding here? I do not see a bug here. the plus addressing was defined by an email provider and that email provider administers these aliases, just as other email providers administer their aliases.
creator: davidsk

content: My guess is that you do not have the alias defined in your account. To function properly, aliases need to be defined in 'managed identities.' Try that and see if that fixes the issue. This is not a bug, and I want to help you get through the issue. thank you
creator: davidsk

content:
david said
My guess is that you do not have the alias defined in your account.

Thank you. Plus addressing is not aliasing. Plus addressing is adding a plus, +, after your name or alias. David, do you use plus addressing?
creator: markfilipak

content: My awareness is with Gmail, where the plus addresses are defined. The email provider needs to acknowledge the plus address. if plus addressing is not dependent on the email provider's awareness, I have not heard of it. Is there a provider that does this?
creator: davidsk

content:
Plus addressing is just gmails way of creating aliases.

You need to define each plus address as an identity in Thunderbird, and then it will work in Thunderbird. You don't need to take my word for it - create an identity and test it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/using-identities

content:
This is how to set fonts for viewing and writing:

- go to TB menu > Settings > General > Language & Fonts > Fonts > click 'Advanced' button

- at the top, set 'Fonts for:' to Latin if it isn't already

- change Proportional and Monospace fonts/sizes to your liking

- set Minimum font size to 14

- at the top, change set 'Fonts for:' to Other Writing Systems

- repeat the process of changing fonts/sizes

- at the bottom, make sure 'Allow messages to use other fonts' is disabled if desired > OK > close the popup
creator: siffemoz

content: the challenge is that thunderbird has tens of thousands of users, using different languages. Thunderbird provides the variety of fonts and character sets to support this wide audience. I agree it takes a number of steps, but once done, it's great. :)
creator: davidsk

content:
I understand that it's a complex system, but a line in the appropriate place under Composition/HML-whatever that says "does not affect Plain Text" or the equivalent shouldn't pose such a burden.

Frank
creator: fhkolwicz1

content: Actually, when one combines HTML font options, the choices get bigger. Persons who just use HTML fonts are usually more confused because thunderbird attempts to minimize impact on recipients, letting them pick their chosen fonts. If you use 'variable font' in HTML, and medium size, NO FONT specs are sent. This is considered good by many, as the recipient isn't dependent on the sender's font. This is one of those issues where we could discuss over beer and peanuts for hours, achieving little more than headaches and calories. :) take care.
creator: davidsk
